description:
Human alphaherpesvirus 3, also known as varicella-zoster virus (VZV), is a member of the Herpesviridae family, specifically the Alphaherpesvirinae subfamily. It is an enveloped, double-stranded DNA virus that primarily infects human hosts.

VZV is the causative agent of two distinct diseases: varicella (chickenpox) and herpes zoster (shingles). During the initial infection, VZV causes the characteristic blistering rash and systemic symptoms of varicella. After the primary infection, the virus can remain latent in the sensory ganglia of the host, and later in life, it can reactivate, leading to the development of herpes zoster, characterized by a painful, localized rash.

The virus primarily spreads through direct contact with infected individuals or through airborne transmission of respiratory droplets. It has a tropism for epithelial cells and neurons, and its ability to establish latency in the host's nervous system is a key feature of its pathogenesis.

VZV is a significant public health concern, as it can cause severe complications, particularly in immunocompromised individuals or those with underlying medical conditions. Vaccination and antiviral therapies are crucial in preventing and managing VZV-related diseases.
